docs.text: 📘 Create a Markdown Documentation Site with MkDocs MkDocs is a static site generator that builds websites from Markdown files. It’s fast, simple, and ideal for technical documentation. 🚀 Step 1: Install MkDocs ✅ Requirements Python 3.6+ pip (Python package manager) 🔧 Installation pip install mkdocs 🧪 Verify installation: mkdocs --version 🏗️ Step 2: Create a New MkDocs Project mkdocs new my-docs-site cd my-docs-site 📁 This creates a basic folder structure: my-docs-site/ ├── docs/ │ └── index.md └── mkdocs.yml docs/ : All your Markdown files go here. mkdocs.yml : Configures your site. ✍️ Step 3: Add Your Markdown Files Add or edit files in the docs/ folder. Example: cd docs touch getting-started.md touch ssh-tutorial.md Edit them with any Markdown editor. 🧭 Step 4: Configure the Site Navigation Edit mkdocs.yml : site_name: My Docs Site nav: - Home: index.md - Getting Started: getting-started.md - SSH Tutorial: ssh-tutorial.md This defines the navigation menu. 👀 Step 5: Preview Your Site Locally Run the built-in development server: mkdocs serve Then visit: http://127.0.0.1:8000 🌀 Live reload is supported — changes are automatically refreshed. 🏁 Step 6: Build the Static Site mkdocs build This creates a site/ directory with static HTML files. 🌐 Step 7: Deploy Your Site GitHub Pages (recommended for free hosting) mkdocs gh-deploy Pushes site/ to the gh-pages branch of your repo. Make sure your project is in a GitHub repository. 🎨 Optional: Use a Custom Theme Install the Material for MkDocs theme: pip install mkdocs-material Update mkdocs.yml : theme: name: material 📁 Folder Summary my-docs-site/ ├── docs/ │ ├── index.md │ ├── getting-started.md │ └── ssh-tutorial.md ├── mkdocs.yml └── site/ ← built files (auto-generated) 🧹 Clean Up Build If needed: mkdocs clean

docs.text: 🧠 Git & GitHub: Complete Tutorial This tutorial covers Git essentials — from installing Git to collaborating with GitHub. 📦 1. Installing Git 🐧 Linux (Debian/Ubuntu) sudo apt update sudo apt install git 🍏 macOS brew install git 🪟 Windows Download from: https://git-scm.com/download/win ⚙️ 2. Git Configuration Set your identity (required for commits): git config --global user.name "Your Name" git config --global user.email "you@example.com" Optional settings: git config --global core.editor "code --wait" # Use VSCode git config --global init.defaultBranch main 📁 3. Starting a Repository Create a new local repository mkdir my-project cd my-project git init Clone a remote repo (e.g., from GitHub) git clone https://github.com/username/repo.git 📝 4. Basic Workflow Check status git status Stage changes git add file1.md file2.py # OR all files git add . Commit changes git commit -m "Describe what you changed" View commit history git log 🌿 5. Branching & Merging Create a branch git branch feature-x Switch branches git checkout feature-x Create and switch git checkout -b feature-x Merge changes Switch to main and merge: git checkout main git merge feature-x Delete a branch git branch -d feature-x 🔁 6. Remote Repositories Add remote git remote add origin https://github.com/username/repo.git Push local changes to remote git push -u origin main Pull remote changes git pull origin main 👥 7. Collaborating via GitHub Forking a repository Click Fork on GitHub. Clone the fork to your local machine. Add the original repo as upstream : git remote add upstream https://github.com/original/repo.git Syncing with upstream git fetch upstream git checkout main git merge upstream/main 🧹 8. Undo & Recovery Undo changes to a file git checkout -- file.txt Unstage a file git reset HEAD file.txt Amend the last commit git commit --amend 🔍 9. Git Tools Command Description git diff Show unstaged changes git stash Save changes temporarily git stash pop Reapply stashed changes git log --oneline Compact log view git show COMMIT_ID Show details of a specific commit 🚀 10. Hosting with GitHub Pages If you're using MkDocs or a static site: mkdocs gh-deploy GitHub will deploy your site from the gh-pages branch. 🧠 Bonus: Helpful .gitignore Create a .gitignore file to ignore untracked files: *.pyc __pycache__/ node_modules/ .env ✅ Summary Workflow git status git add . git commit -m "Message" git pull origin main git push origin main 📚 References Official Git Docs GitHub Docs --- Would you like this tutorial exported as a `.md` file ready for download or deployment in MkDocs?

docs.text: 📘 LaTeX / Overleaf Tutorial This guide helps you get started with LaTeX and Overleaf, including setup, structure, and examples. ✅ What is LaTeX? LaTeX is a typesetting system widely used for technical and scientific writing. It excels at rendering: Mathematical formulas Scientific reports Theses and dissertations Academic articles ✨ Getting Started 🖥️ Option 1: Use Overleaf (Recommended) Go to Overleaf Create a free account Start a new project → it creates a .tex file 🧰 Option 2: Install Locally Install TeX Live (Linux/macOS) or MiKTeX (Windows) Use editors like: TeXstudio VS Code with LaTeX Workshop extension LyX (GUI interface) 🏗️ Basic Document Structure \documentclass{article} \usepackage[utf8]{inputenc} \usepackage{amsmath, amssymb} \usepackage{graphicx} \title{My First LaTeX Document} \author{Your Name} \date{\today} \begin{document} \maketitle \section{Introduction} This is my first \LaTeX{} document. \section{Math Example} Inline: \( E = mc^2 \) Displayed: \[ \int_0^\infty e^{-x^2} dx = \frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{2} \] \section{Lists} \begin{itemize} \item Bullet 1 \item Bullet 2 \end{itemize} \section{Image} \includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{example-image} \end{document} 🧮 Math Mode Examples Type Code Output Inline \( x^2 \) $x^2$ Display \[ \int x^2 dx \] Centered Fraction \frac{a}{b} $\frac{a}{b}$ Greek \alpha , \beta $\alpha, \beta$ 📋 Tables Example \begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline Item & Price \\ \hline Apple & \$1 \\ Banana & \$0.5 \\ \hline \end{tabular} 📎 Including Images \usepackage{graphicx} \begin{figure}[h] \centering \includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{image-file} \caption{Sample Image} \end{figure} Image file must be in the same folder or uploaded in Overleaf. 🔗 Useful Overleaf Tips Use % for comments Recompile manually if needed Share with collaborators Choose a template from the Overleaf Gallery 📦 Common Packages Package Description amsmath Math formulas amssymb Math symbols graphicx Insert images geometry Page layout hyperref Clickable links tikz Draw diagrams 📚 Minimal Overleaf Example \documentclass{article} \usepackage{amsmath} \title{Overleaf Example} \author{Your Name} \date{\today} \begin{document} \maketitle Here is a math formula: \[ f(x) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-x^2} dx \] \end{document} 📌 What's Next? Add bibliographies using BibTeX Create presentations using beamer Learn cross-referencing , \label and \ref Use \input{} or \include{} to organize large projects

docs.text: 🛡️ SSH Tutorial for Beginners SSH (Secure Shell) is a protocol used to securely access and manage remote computers over a network. It provides encrypted communication for login, file transfers, and command execution. 📦 Installing OpenSSH 🖥️ On the Server (Linux) To allow incoming SSH connections, install the OpenSSH Server : Debian/Ubuntu sudo apt update sudo apt install openssh-server Fedora sudo dnf install openssh-server sudo systemctl enable --now sshd Arch Linux sudo pacman -S openssh sudo systemctl enable --now sshd 🔍 Check SSH Status sudo systemctl status ssh It should say active (running) . 🚀 Connecting via SSH (Client) Use this command from your local machine : ssh username@host Example: ssh alice@192.168.1.10 You’ll be prompted to enter the remote password. 🔐 SSH Key-Based Login (Optional but Recommended) 1. Generate a Key Pair (on client) ssh-keygen -t rsa -b 4096 -C "your_email@example.com" Accept defaults ( ~/.ssh/id_rsa ) by pressing Enter. 2. Copy Public Key to Server ssh-copy-id alice@192.168.1.10 You’ll be prompted for the server password one last time . After that, login won’t require a password. 📁 Secure File Transfer with SCP From local to remote: scp file.txt user@remote_host:/remote/path/ Example: scp myfile.txt alice@192.168.1.10:/home/alice/ From remote to local: scp user@remote_host:/remote/file.txt /local/path/ 🔁 Recursively Copy Folders scp -r myfolder user@host:/remote/path/ 🔧 Port Forwarding Tunnel remote services to your local machine: ssh -L 8080:localhost:80 user@host Now localhost:8080 on your machine maps to localhost:80 on the remote server. 🗂️ SSH Config File for Easy Connections Edit or create ~/.ssh/config : Host myserver HostName 192.168.1.10 User alice IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_rsa Port 22 Then simply run: ssh myserver 📋 Summary of Basic SSH Commands Task Command Connect to server ssh user@host Copy file to server scp file.txt user@host:/path/ Copy file from server scp user@host:/file.txt . Copy folder recursively scp -r folder user@host:/path/ Generate SSH key pair ssh-keygen Copy key to server ssh-copy-id user@host Enable port forwarding ssh -L local_port:host:remote_port user@host Configure easy login Edit ~/.ssh/config 🔐 Security Tips Disable root login: Edit /etc/ssh/sshd_config → PermitRootLogin no Change default port: Port 2222 (or similar) in /etc/ssh/sshd_config Use ufw or firewalld to limit SSH access Install fail2ban to block brute-force attacks 🧪 Testing SSH Connection Make sure the server is powered on and connected to the network . Use ping <IP> to verify connectivity. Try connecting with: ssh user@IP_ADDRESS 🔄 Restart SSH Service (if needed) sudo systemctl restart ssh
